page.title: 03AFFORESTATION AT ABLINGTON
page.content: When the airfield used during World War 2 was handed back to private ownership it presented a problem for the farmer, as it was impossible to remove the large volume of concrete. It was solved by breaking up the concrete at planned intervals and planting larch, spruce and beech. The fast growing conifers are gradually being thinned out, leaving the beech. The newly created woods are called "Foxcovert" and "Cinema Piece" where the old Forces' cinema stood, and together with older woodland called "Dead Man's Acre" and "Spring Covert" are now used for the breeding of game, mostly pheasants. Three of the old hangars are still used for the storage of straw and hay.
